experimental_sections:
Materials and methods 253 
 254 
Strains and plasmids 255 
Escherichia coli strains and plasmids used are listed in Table S1. Molecular cloning and 256 
vector propagation were performed in DH5α (NEB). Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) based DNA 257 
replication was performed using KOD XTREME Hot Start Polymerase (MilliporeSigma) for 258 
plasmid backbones. Cloning was performed using Gibson Assembly. Oligos for PCR 259 
amplification and translational knockouts are shown in Table S2. Oligos were purchased from 260 
Integrated DNA Technologies (IDT). The DNA sequence and translated sequence of proteins 261 
overexpressed in this paper are found in Table S3. The pORTMAGE-Ec1 recombineering plasmid 262 
was kindly provided by Timothy Wannier and George Church of Harvard Medical School. 263 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted October 1, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.10.01.679844doi: bioRxiv preprint 
10 
 
Chemicals 264 
The following compounds were purchased from MilliporeSigma: sodium borate 265 
decahydrate, sodium phosphate dibasic anhydrous, chloramphenicol, kanamycin sulfate, dimethyl 266 
sulfoxide (DMSO), boric acid, L-alanine, and HEPES. D-glucose and m-toluic acid. The following 267 
compounds were purchased from Alfa Aesar: agarose and ethanol were purchased. The following 268 
compounds were purchased from Fisher Scientific: isopropyl ß -D-1-thiogalactopyranoside 269 
(IPTG), acetonitrile, sodium chloride, trifluoroacetic acid, LB Broth powder (Lennox), and LB 270 
Agar powder (Lennox). A MOPS EZ rich defined medium kit was purchased from Teknova. Taq 271 
DNA ligase was purchased from GoldBio. Anhydrotetracycline (aTc) was purchased from 272 
Cayman Chemical.  Phusion DNA polymerase and T5 exonuclease were purchased from New 273 
England BioLabs (NEB). Sybr Safe DNA gel stain was purchased from Invitrogen. The following 274 
compounds were purchased from TCI America: Pyridoxal 5’ -phosphate (PLP), ortho-275 
phthalaldehyde and 3-mercaptopropionic acid. 276 
Culture conditions 277 
Cultures were grown in LB -Lennox medium (LB: 10 g/L bacto tryptone, 5 g/L sodium 278 
chloride, 5 g/L yeast extract) or MOPS EZ rich defined media (Teknova M2105) with 2% glucose 279 
(MOPS media). To prepare cells for resting cell assays, confluent overnight cultures of E. coli 280 
strains were used to inoculate 200 mL cultures in LB media in 1 L baffled shake flasks. The 281 
cultures were grown at 37°C until mid -exponential phase (OD600 = 0.5–0.8) and then dropped to 282 
18°C overnight for 18 h. Cells were then pelleted and used or frozen at −80°C. Cells used in this 283 
study were stored at −80°C for less than 24 h.  284 
Aldehyde Stability Assays 285 
For testing stability in metabolically active cells under aerobic growth conditions, cultures 286 
of each E. coli strain to be tested were inoculated from a frozen stock and grown to confluence 287 
overnight in 5 mL of LB media. Confluent overnight cultures were then used to inoculate 288 
experimental cultures to an initial starting OD600 of 0.01 in 400 µL volumes in a 96-deep-well plate 289 
(Thermo Scientific™ 260251) and grown at 37°C. Cultures were supplemented with 5 mM of 290 
aldehyde (prepared in 100 mM stocks in 100% DMSO) at mid -exponential phase (OD600 = 0.5-291 
0.8). Cultures were then incubated at 30°C with shaking at 1000 RPM and an orbital radius of 3 292 
mm. Samples were taken by pipetting 25 µL from the cultures into 125 µL of a 1:4 1 M HCl to 293 
methanol mixture. Samples were then centrifuged in a different 96 -deep-well plate and the 294 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted October 1, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.10.01.679844doi: bioRxiv preprint 
11 
 
extracellular broth was collected. Compounds were quantified over a 24 h period using HPLC with 295 
samples collected at 4 h and 24 h.  296 
For resting cell stability testing, cell pellets were thawed and then washed with 200 mM 297 
HEPES, pH 7.5 buffer. The mass of cell pellets was then measured, and the pellets were 298 
resuspended in 200 mM HEPES, pH 5.8 and 7.5 and at a wet cell weight of 50 mg/mL. The 299 
resuspended resting cells were then aliquoted into 96 -deep-well plates and supplemented with 5 300 
mM aldehydes of interest (prepared in 100 mM stocks in DMSO) at a reaction volume of 400 µL. 301 
Resting cells were then incubated at 30°C with shaking at 1000 RPM and an orbital radius of 3 302 
mm. Samples were taken by pipetting 25 µL from the cultures into 125 µL of a 1:4 1 M HCl to 303 
methanol mixture. Samples were then centrifuged in a different 96 -deep-well plate and the 304 
extracellular broth was collected. Compounds were quantified over a 20 h period using HPLC with 305 
samples collected at 4 h and 20 h. 306 
Growing cell assays 307 
For metabolically active CAR assays, pZE plasmids expressing MaCAR and the Sfp 308 
protein from Bacillus subtilis  were transformed into RARE.Δ16 cultures. Strains were then 309 
inoculated from a frozen stock and grown to confluence overnight in 5 mL of LB media with 50 310 
µg/mL kanamycin. Confluent overnight cultures were then used to inoculate experimental cultures 311 
in a 96-deep-well plate initial starting OD600 of 0.05 in 300 µL in MOPS media with 10 mM MgCl2 312 
and 50 µg/mL kanamycin at pH 7.5. For experiments testing the effect of starting pH, the starting 313 
pH of the MOPS media was titrated to pH ranging from 7.4 -6.75. For experiments testing media 314 
buffering capacity, 100 mM monobasic dihydrogen phosphate were added to cultures. At mid -315 
exponential phase, we induced each culture then supplied 5 mM acid substrate (prepared in 100 316 
mM stocks in 100% DMSO) . Cultures were then incubated at 30°C with shaking at 1000 RPM 317 
and an orbital radius of 3 mm. Samples were taken by pipetting 25 µL from the cultures into 125 318 
µL of a 1:4 1 M HCl to methanol mixture. Samples were then centrifuged in a different 96 -deep-319 
well plate and the extracellular broth was collected. Compounds were quantified over a 24 h period 320 
using HPLC with samples collected at 4 h and 24 h. For pH tracking experiments, confluent 321 
overnight cultures were then used to inoculate 3 mL of MOPs media in 14 mL culture tubes. 322 
Cultures were supplemented with 5 mM of TPA (prepared in a 100 mM stock in DMSO) at mid 323 
exponential phase. Cultures were then incubated at 30°C in a rotor drum (Thermo Scientific Cel -324 
Gro Tissue Culture Rotator) at maximum speed. Sampling was done as previously mentioned. 325 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

12 
 
Compounds were quantified and the pH was measured for 24 h with timepoints at 0 h, 4 h, 8 h, 20 326 
h, and 24 h using HPLC. 327 
For metabolically active ETase assays, pET -28a(+) plasmids expressing each ETase 328 
variant were transformed into RARE.Δ16. Confluent overnight cultures were then used to 329 
inoculate experimental cultures in a 96-deep-well plate initial starting OD600 of 0.05 in 300 µL in 330 
MOPS media with 10 mM MgCl2 and 50 µg/mL kanamycin at pH 7.5. At mid-exponential phase, 331 
we induced each culture then supplied 5 mM BHET, MHET or MHET -ald (prepared in 100 mM 332 
stocks in 100% DMSO). Cultures were then incubated at 30°C with shaking at 1000 RPM and an 333 
orbital radius of 3 mm. Sampling was done as previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified 334 
over a 24 h period using HPLC with samples collected at 4 h and 24 h. 335 
For metabolically active ETase and CAR coupled assays, pACYC-FAST PETase and pZE-336 
MaCAR plasmids were co -transformed into RARE.Δ16. Confluent overnight cultures of pET -337 
28a(+)-FAST PETase (Cell A), pZE-MaCAR (Cell B) and pACYC-FAST PETase + pZE-MaCAR 338 
(Cell C) were then used to inoculate experimental cultures in a monoculture, expressing the dual 339 
plasmid, or a coculture, expressing FAST and MaCAR in separate strains at varying inoculation 340 
ratios. Cultures had an initial starting OD600 of 0.05 in 300 µL in MOPS media with 10 mM MgCl2 341 
and respective antibiotics (Cell C: 17 µg/mL chloramphenicol and 25 µg/mL kanamycin, coculture 342 
and monocultures of Cell A and B: 50 µg/mL kanamycin) at pH 7.5. At mid -exponential phase, 343 
we induced each culture induced (Cell A and B: 0.1 µg/mL aTc; Cell C: 0.1 µg/mL aTc and 1 mM 344 
IPTG) then supplied 5 mM MHET or TPA (prepared in 100 mM stocks in 100% DMSO). Cultures 345 
were then incubated at 30°C. Sampling was done as previously mentioned . Compounds were 346 
quantified over a 24 h period using HPLC with samples collected at 8 h and 24 h. 347 
Growth rate and protein production assay 348 
For growth rate testing of engineered strains, confluent overnight cultures were used to 349 
inoculate experimental cultures in LB or MOPS media at 100x dilution in 200 µL volumes in a 350 
Greiner clear bottom 96 well plate (Greiner 655090). Cultures were grown for 24 h in a Spectramax 351 
i3x plate reader with medium plate shaking at 37 °C and readings at 600 nm taken every 10 min 352 
to determine growth rate of each strain. For growth rate in shake flasks, confluent overnight 353 
cultures were used to inoculate experimental cultures in 50 mL of LB media at 100x dilution in 354 
250 mL shake flasks. Cultures were grown for 9 h at 37 °C and 250 RPMs and readings at 600 nm 355 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted October 1, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.10.01.679844doi: bioRxiv preprint 
13 
 
were taken every 30 min to determine growth rate of each strain using a BioMate160 356 
spectrophotometer. 357 
For growth rate testing with ETase overexpression, confluent overnight cultures were used 358 
to inoculate experimental cultures in MOPS media with 50 µg/mL kanamycin at 100x dilution in 359 
200 µL volumes in a Greiner clear bottom 96 well plate (Greiner 655090). Cultures were grown 360 
for 3 h in a Spectramax i3x plate reader with medium plate shaking at 37 °C with absorbance 361 
readings at 600 nm taken every 10 min to determine growth rate of each strain. Cultures were then 362 
induced with 1 mM IPTG and dropped to 30 °C for an additional 21 h.  363 
TPA protonation state calculation 364 
The protonation state of TPA was calculated using Henderson-Hasselbalch relationship using the 365 
pKa1 = 3.54 and pK a2 = 4.46. The following equations were then used to plot the fraction of 366 
protonated species at the pH range of interest (pH 4.0-8.0) in Fig. S6: 367 
(1) D =1+10 (pH − pKa1) +10 (2pH − pKa1 − pKa2) where D is the denominator fractional abunbances 368 
(2) αTPA = 1 / D where αTPA is the fraction of fully protonated TPA 369 
(3) αTPA- = 10(pH - pKa1) / D where αTPA- is the fraction of partially protonated TPA 370 
(4) αTPA2- = 10(2pH - pKa1 - pka2) / D where αTPA2- is the fraction of fully deprotonated TPA 371 
Translational genomic knockouts 372 
Translational knockouts to the RARE.Δ16 were performed using 10 rounds of multiplexed 373 
automatable genome engineering (MAGE) where stop codons were introduced into the genomic 374 
sequence for each aldehyde dehydrogenase target in the upstream portion of the gene. Construction 375 
of ROARΔ22 was done using the same oligos that were listed for the ROAR.Δ12 strain. MAGE 376 
was performed using the pORTMAGE -Ec1 recombineering plasmid.  Briefly, bacterial cultures 377 
were inoculated with 1:100 dilution in 3 mL of LB media with 30 μg/mL kanamycin (Kan) and 378 
grown at 37°C until OD 600 of 0.4 -0.6 was reached. Then, the proteins responsible for 379 
recombineering were induced with 1 mM m-toluic acid and cultures were grown at 37°C for an 380 
additional 15 min. Cells were then prepared for electroporation by washing 1 mL three times with 381 
refrigerated 10% glycerol and then resuspending in 50 µL of 10% glycerol with each knockout 382 
oligo within a subset added at 1 µM. Cells were then electroporated and recovered in 3 mL of LB 383 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted October 1, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.10.01.679844doi: bioRxiv preprint 
14 
 
with 30 µg/mL kanamycin to be used for subsequent rounds. Preliminary assessment of knockouts 384 
was performed using mascPCR (multiplexed allele specific colony PCR) and confirmed using 385 
Sanger Sequencing. ROAR.Δ22 was cured of the pORTMAGE -Ec1 plasmid following 386 
confirmation of genomic knockouts. 387 
Resting whole cell assays 388 
To prepare cells for resting cell assays, pET-28a(+)-FAST ETase (Cell A), pZE -MaCAR 389 
(Cell B), and pACYC-CvTA-AlaDH (Cell D) were transformed into ROAR.Δ22. pACYC- FAST 390 
ETase and pZE-MaCAR (Cell C) were also co-transformed into ROAR.Δ22. Confluent overnight 391 
cultures were used to inoculate 200 mL cultures in LB media antibiotics (Cell A and B: 50 µg/mL 392 
kanamycin; Cell C: 25 µg/mL kanamycin and 17 µg/mL chloramphenicol; Cell D: 34 µg/mL 393 
chloramphenicol) with 1 L baffled shake flasks. The cultures were grown at 37°C until mid -394 
exponential phase and then induced (Cell A and B: 0.1 µg/mL aTc; Cell C: 0.1 µg/mL aTc  and 1 395 
mM IPTG; Cell D: 1 mM IPTG). After induction the temperature was dropped to 18°C overnight 396 
for 18 h. Cells were then pelleted, and the mass of the cell pellets were then measured. Cells were 397 
used immediately after overexpression or frozen at −80°C. Cells used in this study were stored at 398 
-80°C for less than 24 h. All cells were washed with 200 mM HEPES, pH 7.5 buffer prior to use. 399 
Reactions unless otherwise noted were performed at a reaction volume of 400 µL in 1 mL deep -400 
well plates.  401 
To assay MaCAR (Cell B) in resting cells, cells were resuspended in buffer with 200 mM 402 
HEPES or 200 mM MES (dependent on starting pH), 25 mM glucose, 10 mM magnesium chloride 403 
at pH 5.2-7.5. The resuspended resting cells were then aliquoted into 96-deep-well plates at a wet 404 
cell weight of 50 mg/mL and supplemented with 5 mM substrate of interest (prepared in 100 mM 405 
stocks in DMSO) at a reaction volume of 400 µL. Resting cells were then incubated at 30°C with 406 
shaking at 1000 RPM and an orbital radius of 3 mm. Samples were taken by pipetting 25 µL from 407 
the cultures into 125 µL of a 1:4 1 M HCl to methanol mixture. Samples were then centrifuged in 408 
a different 96 -deep-well plate and the extracellular broth was collected. Compounds were 409 
quantified over a 4 h period using HPLC with samples collected at 2 h and 4 h. 410 
To assay FAST ETase and MaCAR (Cell A+B and Cell C) in resting cells, cells were 411 
resuspended in buffer with 200 mM HEPES, 25 mM glucose, 10 mM magnesium chloride at a pH 412 
7.5. The resuspended resting cells were then aliquoted to a total wet cell weight of 50 mg/mL at 413

varying ratios of FAST ETase to MaCAR cells. Reaction mixture was supplemented with 5 mM 414 
BHET, MHET or TPA at a volume of 400 µL. Resting cells were then incubated at 30°C. Sampling 415 
was done was previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified over a 4 h period using HPLC 416 
with samples collected at 2 h and 4 h. 417 
To assay Cell C with high substrate loading, cells were resuspended in buffer with 400 mM 418 
HEPES, 75 mM glucose, 10 mM MgCl 2 at pH 7.5. Cells were supplemented with 10, 20, or 40 419 
mM of BHET or MHET at a cell concentration of 50 mg WCW/mL and at a volume of 400 µL. 420 
Compounds were quantified over an 8 h period using HPLC with samples collected at 4 h and 8 421 
h. 422 
To assay CvTA-AlaDH (Cell D) in resting cells, cells were resuspended in buffer with 200 423 
mM HEPES or 200 mM MES, 25 mM glucose, 10 mM MgCl2, 100 mM L-alanine, 50 mM NH4Cl 424 
and 1 mM PLP at pH 5.8-8.0. The resuspended resting cells were then aliquoted to a total wet cell 425 
weight of 50 mg/mL and supplemented with 5 mM TPAL. Resting cells were then incubated at 426 
30°C. Sampling was done was previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified using HPLC at 427 
2 h. 428 
To assay Cell B and D in a one-pot two-step method, cells were resuspended in buffer with 429 
200 mM HEPES, 200 mM MES, 25 mM glucose, 10 mM MgCl 2, 100 mM L -alanine, 50 mM 430 
NH4Cl and 1 mM PLP at a pH of 5.2 or 7.5. To start the reaction, Cell B was added to the reaction 431 
mixture at 50 mgWCW/mL and at a starting pH of 5.2 or 7.5. The cells were then supplemented with 432 
5 mM TPA disodium salt and incubated at 30°C. After 2 h, the low starting pH reaction mixtures 433 
were treated to 7.5 using NaOH. Also, at 2 h both starting pH reactions were supplemented with 434 
50 mgWCW/mL of CvTA cells. The reactions were then ran for an additional 2 h. Sampling was 435 
done was previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified at 4 h using HPLC. 436 
To assay Cell A+B, Cell C and Cell D in one-pot with resting cells, cells were resuspended 437 
in buffer with 200 mM HEPES, 25 mM glucose, 10 mM MgCl2, 100 mM L-alanine, 50 mM NH4Cl 438 
and 1 mM PLP at a pH of 7.5.  For pXYL targeted reactions,  Cells A and B were added to the 439 
reaction mixture at different ratios (1:2, 1:1. 2:1, 1:5 and 1: 10 of Cell A: Cell B) with a total cell 440 
concentration of 50 mgWCW/mL. Cell C was also added at a cell concentration of 50 mg WCW/mL. 441 
The cells were then supplemented with 5 mM BHET, MHET or TPA and incubated at 30°C. After 442 
2 h, 50 mgWCW/mL of Cell D was added and the reaction was then ran for an additional 2 h. 443

Sampling was done was previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified at 4 h using HPLC.  444 
For pAMBA targeted reactions, Cells A, B and D were added to the reaction mixture at different 445 
ratios (2:1:1, 1:2:1. 1:10:2, and 1:1:2 of Cell A: Cell B: Cell D) with a total cell concentration of 446 
50 mgWCW/mL. Cells C and D were also added at different ratios (10:1, 5:1 and 1:1 of Cell C: 447 
CellD) with a total cell concentration of 50 mgWCW/mL. The cells were then supplemented with 5 448 
mM MHET and incubated at 30°C. Sampling was done was previously mentioned. Compounds 449 
were quantified at 4 h using HPLC. 450 
Amine production from real PET glycolysis products 451 
To assay Cell C using real PET glycolysis deconstruction products, cells were resuspended 452 
in buffer with 400 mM HEPES, 75 mM glucose, 10 mM MgCl 2, 200 mM L -alanine, 100 mM 453 
NH4Cl and 1 mM PLP at pH 7.8.  Solid PET glycolysis products were resuspended in 500 µL 454 
DMSO and added to the reaction mixture at a targeted 40 mM BHET concentration. Reactions 455 
were conducted using a 50 mL conical tube with a total reaction volume of 10 mL. Sampling was 456 
done was previously mentioned. Compounds were quantified over an 8 h period using HPLC with 457 
samples collected at 4 h and 8 h. 458 
PET glycolysis 459 
Plastic PET glycolysis experiments were carried out under previously optimized 460 
conditions52 using a Monowave 450 microwave reactor (Anton Paar GmbH), equipped with an in-461 
built IR sensor and an external Ruby thermometer for precise temperature control, Commercial 462 
PET beverage bottles (Coca -Cola) were washed with water, dried, and cut into ~4 mm × 4 mm 463 
square pieces prior to use. 464 
In a typical experiment, 500 mg of PET flakes, 5 mL of ethylene glycol (EG), and 5 mg of 465 
catalyst were added to a microwave reaction vial. Commercial ZnO nanopowder (<5 μm particle 466 
size, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as the catalyst. The contents of the vial were thoroughly mixed 467 
using a vortex mixer to ensure uniform dispersion of ZnO in EG. The vial was then placed in the 468 
microwave reactor, which was programmed to maintain a constant temperature of 210°C for 15 469 
minutes with a stirring speed of 600 rpm. 470 
After the reaction, the vial was rapidly cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, 100 mL 471 
of distilled water was added to extract BHET. Unreacted PET and higher molecular weight 472

oligomers were removed by filtration using Whatman filter paper. The filtrate, containing water -473 
soluble products, was analysed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). 474 
The residual water in the product solution was evaporated under vacuum (72 mbar) at 40°C 475 
using a rotary evaporator. BHET was then crystallized by cooling the concentrated solution 476 
overnight at 4°C in a refrigerator, following the addition of a small volume of distilled water. The 477 
resulting BHET crystals were collected by filtration using a glass filter, thoroughly washed to 478 
remove any residual EG, and dried overnight at 80°C. 479 
The conversion of PET is calculated as follows: 480 
PET Conversion (%) =
WPET,i − WPET,f
WPET,i
× 100 (1) 481 
WPET,i corresponds to the initial weight of PET and W PET,f to the weight of the unreacted PET, 482 
obtained via filtration. The yield of the BHET is defined as: 483 
BHET Yield (%) =  
molBHET
molPET
× 100  (2) 484

WPET,i
MWPET−RU
  (3) 485 
Textile depolymerization experiments were carried out at previously optimized 486 
conditions51. Depolymerization experiments were performed on a Monowave 450 microwave 487 
reactor (Anton Paar GmbH). This batch microwave reactor controls the temperature, time, and 488 
maximum set power. Typically, 500 mg of textiles, 5 mL of EG, and 5 mg of the catalyst were 489 
placed in a microwave reaction vial. The vial was inserted into the microwave reactor, and the 490 
reactor was programmed to maintain a constant temperature. On completion of a reaction, the 491 
reaction vial was allowed to cool down rapidly to room temperature. 100 mL of distilled water was 492 
added to separate BHET and oligomers. The unreacted polymer and larger oligomers were 493 
removed using a Whatman filter paper. The residual water from the product solution was then 494 
evaporated under vacuum (72 mbar) at 60 °C using a rotary evaporator, and the resulting BHET 495 
was crystallized by cooling the residual solution overnight to 4 °C in a refrigerator after the 496 
addition of a small amount of distilled water to the residue. The resultant crystals were filtered 497 
using a glass filter and dried at 80 °C. 498 
HPLC analysis 499

TPAL, 4HMB, 4HMBA, BDM  and pXYL were quantified using reverse -phase high -500 
performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with an Agilent 1260 Infinity with a Zorbax Eclipse 501 
Plus-C18 column with a guard column installed. Amines were derivatized with ortho-502 
pthalaldehyde and 3-mercaptopropionic acid and identified using reverse-phase high-performance 503 
liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC) with an Agilent 1260 Infinity with a Zorbax Eclipse Plus-C18 504 
column with a guard column installed. The methods for detection of TPAL, 4HMB, 4HMBA, 505 
BDM and pXYL were described previously36. 506
